segments.text: delay.
This is the Japanese revision.
Let me tell you about Brunette Thorson's film collection.
Okay.
Now, here's what I'm interested in, really, is that there has been, as a matter of fact,
over the last five or six years, almost, well, really since 1957, since the IGY, has been an increased exchange of Soviet and American scientists upon international cruises.
Cooperation in Moho, for example, and in working plate tectonics.
Why your committee?
Why now?
Did that lead to an evolution of international cooperation so they thought that a group like you could ensure continued cooperation?
Well, no, I don't think it was to ensure it.
I think it was to expand it.
A lot of the cooperation that you have mentioned has been limited to high seas, oceanographic vessel effort.
There has not been much involvement at shore facilities.
The occasional, yeah, but not as much.
For example, I visited the Soviet Union as a guest of their academy in the fall of 74, going around the long way, taking a cruise ship of the Soviet Union from Yokohama.
Okay, so I came into Nohodka, which is close to Vladivostok, but I'm not permitted to visit Vladivostok.

I was the first U.S. scientist ever to visit that area, and as luck would have it, since it was the summer, there were perhaps 300 marine biology, oceanography people from all over the Soviet Union working at that laboratory.

it was a fabulous opportunity to talk with people that you had never met maybe never will meet again but it developed for me a list of names and addresses with whom i can correspond some of whom i will undoubtedly see again but here is a tremendous block of the soviet scientific community that have never even seen a u.s scientist before and the same i think could be said for a sizable
scientific community.
Now, how were you tapped for this kind of committee assignment?
Why did they pick you?
Okay, I think it's pretty cut and dry.
In 66, in part because of the earlier involvement, I had an opportunity to participate in the second international oceanographic congress, Moscow.

I went, spent about a month in the Soviet Union, a portion of which was at the meetings in Moscow, and a portion was at the post-Congress tour of facilities on the Black Sea, Sevastopol, Sochi, Yalta.
That gave me contact with Soviet scientists, and for the ten years that followed,
I maintained these contacts through correspondence, exchange of scientific publications.

In 72, at a meeting in Helgeland, which is Germany, another very, very influential gentleman in the realm of marine biology, not oceanography, Otto Kinnett, had invited three Soviet scientists as guests of the German Republic.
Two of them
were people that I had met at the 66th Oceanographic Congress.

In the six or seven years that we had not seen each other, one of them had been kicked way upstairs as a member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, a director of the new Far Eastern Institute of Marine Biology, Vladivostok.
We spent some number of evenings catching each other up.
And it was from that that I received the invitation to go there as their guest.
And I assume that when this was known,
And they were looking for US people to serve on these committees.
My name just happened to come out of the computer.
So all these things are so interrelated that sometimes it really defies the imagination.
Do you anticipate, we were, actually you were spelling out goals, which your committee had in mind.
And we don't, you had really only talked of one goal.
Now, you're going to create subcommittees then.
When do you anticipate subcommittees' reports with goals for a national corporation?
One of the programs in that general biological productivity and biochemistry of the world's oceans is a section on the ecology of fouling communities, with which I am personally involved.
The first of the workshops was scheduled for Beaufort, November 75.
In spite of rather horrendous difficulties, which are the sort of thing that would make a good short story, a group of Soviet scientists came here.
We had the workshop with about 22 US scientists.
We, in addition to presenting, review papers from both sides to familiarize the other side with what's going on in the realm of the ecology of filing communities.
There was a lot of after dinner discussions, individual chats, presentation of short scientific papers, and more importantly, a lot of talk about where should we go from here.

One of the places that we are going from there is to Leningrad in late November 76 for a return workshop, which will do the reverse in the sense that it will take eight U.S. scientists to meet with about 30 Soviet scientists.
In the year that they've had since the Beaufort meeting, they are encouraged to communicate with their Soviet counterparts
begin to think on their own as to individual research and cooperative research projects that they feel should be attempted.
The proceedings of that 75 workshop are to be published in the next six weeks by the Navy Printing Office in both languages.
And as the first volume resulting from this whole

program it will be widely distributed through the soviet union and the united states hopefully generating interest thoughts on research that some soviet might wish to do in this country and some u.s might wish to do in the soviet union

at the November Leningrad meeting we will be more specific about okay now who is available from the scientific community to go to the Soviet Union during the summer months of 1977 and develop some sort of a cooperative research program either with a group from Leningrad or Moscow or Vladivostok and get the whole thing geared up so that it isn't one of these nebulous paper things but a whole series of reasonably
well-organized individual efforts rather than a monstrous program.
The language handicap, how great is it?
It's serious, but less serious at the scientific level than at the political level.
And you see this in discussions with the Soviets all the time.
When the group came here in May for their working party meeting, they brought with them their own interpreter.
We provided an interpreter also.
In casual conversations about science, nobody seems to worry too much about whether I say mollusks or molluscans.

But when it comes to formulating the protocol, then there was frequently a 15-minute discussion between their interpreter and our interpreter as to the nuances of the words that should be used, because it comes out as a Soviet version plus a US version, which must agree.
But many of the Russians speak English far better than we speak Russian.
It's standard procedure, I guess, through the academy that when you go there, you are provided with an interpreter.
And it will take a long time before it's as comfortable as it is with, say, the people in the German scientific community.
But it's moving in that direction.
And the area that bothers me most is that there is a tremendous backlog of scientific literature in Russian that most US scientists have never seen and cannot read, even if they know it exists.
Do you read and speak Russian?
No.
But at some point, we're going to have to tackle the problem of translating the significant works that can't do it all.
And the big trick is to decide what's significant.
and then proceed to translate it and print it and disseminate it.
They do this all the time on a laboratory base, but we don't.
Now, you were involved with the EPA in 1975, too, on an Environmental Protection Agency conference on estuaries.
Was this also in connection with your work in international cooperation?
Would this overlap?
Oh yeah, there's a lot of overlap.
I don't know why I was selected to participate in that, but possibly because I have been involved in estuarine research for 25 years, so that I know a lot of the people who are
concerned about environmental and estuarine pollution.
And I guess I've published a lot on it, so it would be natural.
Now, are you able to bring in your experience at international conferences and your discussion with your contemporaries and colleagues here?
Oh, very definitely.
And encourage them to the extent that they are so inclined to take advantage of the contacts that I have.
And that's one of the reasons that I push

much the amusement of some of my colleagues to bring to this laboratory scientists from all over the world either individually when they're coming through the United States or as a group like this Soviet working party meeting that's why I wanted it here so that they could chat with the members of the staff here and begin to develop whatever interests that they may have I have two or three technical questions and I want to turn back to
cooperation, really.
But what forms of life are first hit the hardest by shoreline pollution?
Well, presumably the sessile form.
Any of the shelf, well, not any of the shelf, the shrimps can move around, but the clams, the oysters, they can't get away from it.
So they close up for a while, and if they can't stay closed up beyond a certain point, that's it.
Now, the average American probably identifies Jacques Cousteau as the prominent oceanographer in the world.
And this is the media's message.
Now, in dealing as a scientist, and this is a very involved question I have here, but as a scientist dealing with pollution on shore,
obviously shellfish are the first one to take the blows of pollutants.
Do you feel yourself pressured between those people who identify with many of Cousteau's rash statements on one side and with private enterprise on the other, not anxious to protect the shellfish?
Well, gee, first of all, I don't view Cousteau as a scientist.
That's where the media have distorted the message.
There is no doubt that
He has done more for the realm of oceanography in the public eye than any other man, but as a promoter, not as a scientist.
And this is why when he comes here and makes some of his sweeping generalities, it's hard to convince people within the Congress, say, that he is speaking as a promoter, not as a scientist.
Sometimes the shock value of what he has had to say carries enough that you do see some results from it, even though what he said originally is debatable.
And this is, of course, one of the problems in the scientific community.
We're always arguing about the hairs of definitions of things as apart from the overviews that Cousteau takes.
And in that sense, he undoubtedly has
contributed a great deal.
But I'm not sure I know.
Pressured between private enterprise and Cousteau, I don't see it that way at all.
Well, maybe my question was not phrased properly.

I was saying that Cousteau, as what amounts to a naturalist promoter, tends to make these rash statements about the Mediterranean dying or the Red Sea will soon be gone or soon there will be no life in the ocean is the one that sticks in my mind, which stirs up, in particularly coastal states like yours, a great deal of opinion
among environmentalists about what should be done.

Do you feel a great deal of pressure as a man attached to an institution in this state like Duke University between these environmentalists spurred on by people like Cousteau and private enterprise, which has not won any records in North Carolina, by the way, for preserving the shoreline?
That's a sore point.
How do you react to that?
What's your personal reaction to that?
To these two different opinions?
To this sort of pressure, this internal pressure, if there is such, created within your state itself.
Well, without
someone like Cousteau to influence the man in the street, it would be a losing cause.
Because most scientists are not capable of conveying to the man in the street the real problems.
They're too concerned about the details.
They're not capable of putting it into language that people can understand.
And it's going to be up to somebody like Cousteau and Ralph Nader to
sufficiently aroused the public to permit the government to do some of the things that the scientific community thinks should be done.
What sort of positive steps should we take?
Well...
I think the simplest initial step would be to enforce the laws that exist.
We have a big fight right now in this county over coastal management.
And the state in 72 passed, no in 74, passed the Coastal Management Act, which is modeled pretty much after the Federal Coastal Management Act of 72.
And they are now in the process of getting the 20 coastal counties to organize a land use plan.
This county, which ironically enough was the only county to support coastal management in 74,

has now filed suit against the state declaring that the law is unconstitutional which means that in the meantime we're going to be without any sort of land use planning the county commissioners in yesterday's paper indicated that they intend to fill the void by starting a very thorough and exacting review of the existing ordinances in this county relative to the environment and to their enforcement

Well, if they will do this, it may be a new day dawning, because right now there are flagrant violations of existing county ordinances on the use of septic tanks, for example, the development of trailer parks, and how many trailers can be attached to a septic tank.
And if they will really enforce this, then we'll be a lot farther ahead.
Well, the same thing can be said, I'm pretty sure, of all coastal states.
to varying degrees.
You pass a law to appease some group and then you forget it.
You don't try to enforce it.
So that would be a start.
The other thing, at a higher level, I think the EPA is finally recognizing that you can't develop environmental constraints on estuaries as a whole.
You've got to accept the fact that estuaries in Alaska are different from estuaries in Florida.

And it's going to take a further subdivision of U.S. regional problems and then specific ordinances, laws, call them what you will, measures to deal with those problems in specific areas and not try to blanket Alaska and Florida.

But none of this will come about if the public doesn't demand it, and if they don't realize that when scientists talk about the concern for the small fiddler crabs, they're not really expressing a value judgment of fiddler crabs against people.
They're using the fiddler crabs as a barometer of the way in which the environment is going.
that the corrective measures will have to be brought about because the public understands that this is what it is and insists that we clean it up.

Yet somehow my view of oceanography is one which has been deeply involved with private enterprise and with the military as well as with practical sciences and impractical sciences, if I may use that word.
Do you feel tensions within your profession?
based upon this kind of cooperation?
Well, I don't know of much involvement between private enterprise and oceanography.
I was thinking about the oil industry.
Well, that's almost exclusively geology.
And geologists as a group, and they'll shoot me for it, but frequently geologists are not that concerned about the environment itself.
They're more interested in the way in which it was formed, the way in which it evolves.
It's an abstract, non-living system, so that they are not necessarily as attuned to the problems of pollution relative to biological systems.
And I don't say that as a derogatory statement.
I'm not that familiar with the
But if you look at the realm of biological oceanography, there's very little involvement with private enterprise.
In fact, none of my colleagues have jobs with private enterprise.
Then, as far as you're concerned, scientists and EPA then, or what have you, could cooperate without any problems.
Oh, yeah.
Intellectually or financially or whatever.
The only place we get in trouble are under political constraints.
All right.
Now, what do you say to the Russians then, back to where I left you, what do you say to the Russians then when they point out the problems of pollution you have at home?
Do you ever discuss these sorts of things?
They have the same problems at home, too.
Okay.
I was going to say, yeah, it would seem the Russians would say, how can you offer me advice?
Look at what's occurring off of Louisiana, for example.
The problems of pollution in the Soviet Union are almost identical to the problems of pollution in the United States.
It's just a question of what you call the group that is contributing to the pollution.
Over there, it's a collective something or other owned by the state.
Over here, it is a private industry owned by the stockholders.
But the results are the same.
And the example that I always fall back on is Lake Baikal.
Here is one of the oldest, deepest freshwater lakes in the world, full of all sorts of exotic fauna left over from the millennia gone by.
And there is a very serious threat to the lake now because of industry, state industry.

and there has been a local effort to drum up support for cleaning up Lake Baikal and a land use plan which will prevent any further industry from being situated on the banks of Lake Baikal and restrictive measures on what can be pumped in terms of effluents into Lake Baikal.
All you have to do is substitute a certain number of titles and administrative units and you've got the same problem in North Carolina.
You've got to put the stuff someplace.
And it doesn't matter whether you're a communist state or a capitalist state, you're going to have problems when you start putting it into the natural environment.
Now, you wouldn't see a mass demonstration in the streets of Moscow saying, down with state industries.
That's the major difference.
Do you think progress is being made?
Definitely.
But that's where some perspective in terms of history is useful, because man never progresses as fast as some people think he should.
But locally, nationally, and internationally, you would adjudge progress to occur?
Very definite.
Well, let me say something.
If you and I had been talking 10 years ago, let's say it's now August 10th, 1967, 1966,
Much of what we have discussed in the last 10 minutes couldn't have been discussed because there wasn't any program, really.
There wasn't any environmental protection agency.
Only a few voices in the wilderness were beginning to say, we must do something about the environment.
And the book Silent Spring, which was written basically right outside of this laboratory, was the first real recognition that we were in trouble.
And I think it is really outstanding that in the last five years we have made the inroads and alerted the public and educated the public to the extent that we have done.
when he, of course, as he turned out to be correct in almost every single point.
It was the most amazing book I ever read.
And when I asked him about it, he said, well, you've got to watch these people using scare tactics.
And, of course, as you point out, now this conversation is just considered an important part of now international cooperation.
Now, when did you first notice the environment becoming important on the international level?
What were the first conferences you were involved in where this became the focal point of discussion?
I guess it was the Rome meeting of FAO in 1970, and there it applied exclusively to the marine environment.
I think that was the first really formal recognition that the topic received.
There were some number of earlier national meetings, and you could go to a meeting
in another country, say in 67 or 8, and people would be talking about it.
But you would not have found that within the meeting there was a whole section devoted to environmental problems.
Now, how did you come to organize a conference on land development of marine invertebrates in Yugoslavia?
Well, you better change that title.
It's larval development.
I'm sorry, lowerable developments.
Well, for several reasons.
Yugoslavia at that time had PL-480 funds.
And through my involvement with the Smithsonian, I knew of the machinery involved with PL-480 funds.
So once I was off of the Biological Advisory Committee,
where it wouldn't have been appropriate for me to submit a proposal on my own.
I submitted a proposal as a member of the scientific community for such a conference because of my connections throughout the European scientific community.
There was no real difficulty in generating enthusiasm and finding participants.
And the same applied to the U.S. participants who went.
I had long wanted to do a

second larval conference we did one here in 67 and here was just about everything that was required for such a conference the facilities the interest and the financial support yugoslavia how would you rank yet in terms of a sign a comparison with western science well you can't label yugoslavia because it's a series of what five
small states or varying sized states.
And the degree of difference within these five is astronomical.
In the northern area you have, for all practical purposes, western science.
In the southern area, right next to Albania, the state of Montenegro, the understanding of science is about where it was in 1903.
And then you have various gradations in between.
The Split Institute of Oceanography, which is a major Yugoslav oceanographic institution, has some excellent people, some good equipment.
They don't have the support that they would like, but that's true most places.
Their interests are far more provincial in the sense that most of their emphasis is on either the Adriatic or
Mediterranean, but that's understandable.
They can't afford a monstrous international program, and there's no reason why they should feel they should.
What a country like Yugoslavia, which I think we would consider underdeveloped in our terms, particularly in southern Yugoslavia, are they interested in such things as environmental controls too?
Oh, very definitely, for very practical reasons.
In a number of areas,
They have developed some fantastic tourist facilities in response to domains on the part of the rest of Europe.
And they're on a collision course in certain areas between industry and tourism, heavy industry.
They're having problems with what to do with all the sewage produced by all the tourists.
So they have very good everyday practical reasons why they need to know more about offshore currents, the effect of pollutants on the fauna,
If they pollute the Adriatic, which wouldn't take that much, what little fishing they now have is down the drain.
But, of course, it's a much more complicated situation in that the Yugoslavs don't get along too well with the Italians.
The Italians have the beach across the hall, and the Italians have not been too concerned about polluting.
